results.content:
The few rough spots in the course (slightly dated material, varying standards, e.g. e or event) are not an issue but could be cleaned up if time permits.  This course clearly provides insight into the underpinnings of Progressive Web Apps.  It is a lot to digest and the instructor knows that not every concept will be understood immediately by the learner so he edits his commentary very well.
Final note:  There are a few videos which have different titles but are in fact the same video.  Usually back to back and are marked with the same duration in minutes.

results.content: A bit long and very thorough. You can skip to the parts which interest you, of course. Most of the course is good quality there are some random quality issues like videos cutting off, audio issues. But 24 hours of content there are going to be hick ups. I think it would have been nice if the author of the course would have organized the lectures a little more so there would be less repetition. But then again the repetition is kind of nice just so I can remember the concepts more. Of course, this is my first time through the course just to get a general over and then I will go back and rewatch/reread the parts that I need to.

results.content:
There’s a lot of good material in here, but it’s very poorly organized. As a result, it becomes repetitive. Furthermore, the work on the individual chapters is sloppy at times. Duplicate videos. Videos that end mid sentence. Videos that go on well after the talking has stopped. 

You might want to skip to lecture 95ish to avoid a lot of repetitive hype about progressive web applications. And ignore anything about Safari because all of that information is outdated.
results.content_html:

You might want to skip to lecture 95ish to avoid a lot of repetitive hype about progressive web applications. And ignore anything about Safari because all of that information is outdated.

results.content: Very thorough coverage of all relevant topics.
results.content_html: Very thorough coverage of all relevant topics.

results.content:
The course is a good broad overview of PWAs. But it felt like the production was rushed. There were several basic quality issues:
- Media problems. The mic scratches frequently, like there's a loose connection. One lecture was just a black screen for the first 2/3. The instructor never bothers to move his mouse pointer out of view, which gets to be a problem when you're following along and see two cursors on the screen.
- Disjointed curriculum. Modules are not consistently ordered logically so concepts are presented without background and you have to kind of fill in the gaps later.
- Repeated lectures. Several pairs of lectures are just the same video repeated. Examples: lecture 109/111, 121/122, 154/156, 163/164. Really makes you feel like he didn't put much effort into it.

response.content:
I am sorry for some of the technical issues. I have been working to clean those up. 
I am not trying to blame Udemy because their admin interface is done well, but managing content uploads of this volume (21+hours) is quite a learning process.
And as far as putting effort in, trust me I did and continue to do so. 21 hours of video on technical content means I put in at least 200 hours of prep :)
response.content_html:

results.content: Most of the content does not seem to really relate to progressive web apps, many lectures focus on details that don't seem relevant and which most developers should already know anyway.

response.content:
It would be great if you can list some topics you think should not be covered. I regularly interact with developers online and at events and conferences, and feel I have a reasonable insight into what questions developers have.
For example I rarely encounter developers with any experience or knowledge of the fetch API, which is critical to developing service workers.

results.content: Lorsque que le formateur dit qu'il va mettre à jour le repository du cours, ça serait bien qu'il le fasse. C'est comme s'il ne tenait pas compte des remarques des élèves. Je suis déçu par cette attitude.

response.content: I am in the process of updating the source code repository. I ran into some technical issues pushing the large repo to GitHub. I recently sent out a communication relaying that effort. My plan is to almost redo the entire example application and the source data to make it cleaner.

There are lots of vídeos, where the core concepts can be explain in 5 minutos but the author takes double o triple.

I regret have not audited the course before, now I lost my chances of refund.

Very poor use of visuals, there are long vídeos with very few images and a lot of bla bla bla, without going to the point.

response.content:
The first few lectures are designed to give you a firm understanding of what Progressive Web Apps are. Most developers are still very confused by the concept, so I feel it is critical to explain the concepts for everyone.
The great thing about a course like this is you can skip content you don't find relevant and go straight to the content you feel you need. :)
This is one reason why I broke the lectures up into small segments.

results.content: The content is very repetitive and very basic. The delivery of this content is very poor. I did not get very far before I realized the content also feels very old. I kept saying "of course we should do things like this".

response.content:
Sorry you feel that way. If you can share how far you got that would be helpful. I have considered moving the content to describe what a progressive web app is.
If you want to get into more of the coding concepts you can always skip ahead to those sections. ;) That is how I treat most online courses so I can maximize my time.
I want the course to have content for developers with every skill level and many are new to web development and the concepts of progressive web apps.

results.content: Don't waste time on this. Unnecessarily long.

response.content:
Sorry you feel that way. To properly cover progressive web apps I really felt like topics need to be covered in depth. I will be updating content over the next month and probably adding even more. 
The great thing about a course like this on a platform like Udemy is the content can be skipped you don't feel you need. You can always use the content as reference material when you need to solve specific questions.
I want this course to be the go to reference for developers to deliver great user experiences with Progressive Web Apps.
